qas.question: In what form does the Quran say God sends his messages to people?
Who intermediates between God and prophets?
Which part of the Quran describes God's use of intermediaries between himself and his prophets?
How does the Quran describe the similarity of messages God has delivered throughout human history?
Which humans are the messengers of God?
In what form doesn't the Quran say God sends his messages to people?
Who intermediates between Jesus and prophets?
Which part of the Quran describes Mohammed's use of intermediaries between himself and his prophets?
How does the Quran describe the differences of messages God has delivered throughout human history?
Which nonhumans are the messengers of God?

context: According to the Quran, God communicated with man and made his will known through <a0_0><b5_0>signs and revelations<b5_0/><a0_0/>. <a4_0><b9_0>Prophets<b9_0/><a4_0/>, or 'Messengers of God', received revelations and delivered them to humanity. The message has been <a3_0><b8_0>identical<b8_0/><a3_0/> and for all humankind. "Nothing is said to you that was not said to the messengers before you, that your lord has at his Command forgiveness as well as a most Grievous Penalty." The revelation does not come directly from God to the prophets. <a1_0><b6_0>Angels<b6_0/><a1_0/> acting as God's messengers deliver the divine revelation to them. This comes out in Quran <a2_0><b7_0>42:51<b7_0/><a2_0/>, in which it is stated: "It is not for any mortal that God should speak to them, except by revelation, or from behind a veil, or by sending a messenger to reveal by his permission whatsoever He will."
